game_machine.container module¶

class game_machine.container.Container¶

Bases: object

A Container allows a hierarchy of visual objects to be constructed

A container is either a single object, in which case a call to its draw method calls the draw method of the child class, or if it is not single, then it maintains a list of child instances, and a call to draw calls the draw method on all the child instances.

game_machine.screen module¶

class game_machine.screen.Screen(size=(0, 0), colour=(255, 255, 255), title='Game machine window', cartesian=True)¶

Bases: game_machine.container.Container, game_machine.eventobject.EventObject

Screen is the central class for Game Machine.

Screen places a window on the desktop onto which Game Machine graphics can be drawn. It detects mouse and keyboard events and passes them onto the interactive elements that are created in Game Machine. It also does lots of ‘under the bonnet’ work to initialise Game Machine and get it working.

add(child)¶
close()¶

close closes the screen and shuts down pygame

draw(update=False, fps=12)¶

update calls update on all the child sprites and then draws all the child sprites on the screen. It then waits according the fps (frames per second) argument

Module contents¶

Game Machine¶

Game Machine is a wrapper for pygame, intended to make an extremely shallow learning curve for getting a decently engaging game working. It is intended to be an educational tool for complete programming novices, or as a bridge from Scratch to Python.

It was developed as part of the This Machine Kills Zombies project, which introduces Python programming on the Raspberry Pi. It should, however, be completely portable to other platforms and projects.

Just to restate: Game Machine is not intended to be a replacement for, or improvement on pygame.
